Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Functional Nanostructures based on the self assembly of Verdazyl Free Radicals
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RUI project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor David J. R. Brook of San Jos√© State University will investigate the coordination chemistry of verdazyl free radicals; in particular their incorporation into functional, self assembled nano-structures. Verdazyl radicals exhibit some of the highest reported magnetic exchange interactions with coordinated ions and show reversible one electron oxidation and reduction; however, the number of reported verdazyl coordination compounds is still rather low and the nature of the metal-radical interaction is relatively poorly understood. Studies of verdazyl radicals synthesized using recently established methods will investigate phenomena such as magnetic exchange, spin crossover, valence tautomerization. Techniques and insight from these studies will be used to develop polytopic verdazyl ligands capable of self assembly to produce functional nanostructures with novel electronic structure and magnetic properties. In the context of information storage we will particularly aim for multistable systems where the molecule may be reversibly switched between several states by physical or chemical stimuli. We anticipate that the development of a new series of paramagnetic ligands has transformative potential in the area of magnetochemistry and molecular devices.

Students involved in this project will use a broad range of experimental techniques including synthesis, NMR spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, vibrational spectroscopy, UV-vis, electrochemistry, magnetochemistry and X-ray crystallography. The breadth of the research will allow contributions from MS level graduate students, through freshmen and even advanced high school students. Students are expected to present their research at local, regional and national meetings, in addition to participation in preparation of manuscripts for publication. These activities will increase our graduates preparation for further study at the graduate level or participation in an industrial research setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RUI: Functional Nanostructures Based on the Self-Assembly of Verdazyl Radicals

In this project we set out to design and build molecules (called verdazyl free radicals) that are unusual in that they have unpaired electrons ( in most molecules the electrons are paired ) and that spontaneously assemble together in a predictable way by binding metal ions. The idea is to use the assembly to control the interaction between the unpaired electrons and give molecules with new magnetic properties.

Over the past four years, we made several of our target molecules. In the process we found that the chemistry is more complex that we anticipated, and though we proposed and made structures with up to four metal ions holding them together, we found that even the structures with only one metal ion show unusual properties. Unexpectedly we found that with some metal ions, one of the electrons can switch back and forth between the metal atom and the molecule attached to the metal atom, depending upon the environment  of the molecule. Such effects have been seen before but not in the class of molecules that we are looking at. We are still working on understanding how this switching process works, and in the future will look at how neighboring 'switches' interact with each other when we build larger systems.

In the broader scheme of things, such switchable molecules may have application in information storage or computation at the molecular level. In the process of doing the research we have also discovered new ways of making verdazyls which will enable them to be used in  other areas such as new electronic materials, sensors, and molecular sized probes for biological systems.

Students working on the project also gained significant experience in chemical research using a large variety of techniques. Six of the students involved in the project have gone on to doctoral programs in chemistry where their research experience on this project form part of their training as scientists. Others have gone to professional schools in pharmacy and medicine.
